mn27:0.2.eng: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

mn27:1.1.comm: This sutta urges against drawing rash conclusions, insisting on a cautious and pragmatic approach to the truth. The theme of epistemological caution is further developed in such suttas as MN 47, MN 60, and MN 99. | According to the Sinhalese chronicle Mahāvaṁsa 14.22, this was the first discourse taught by the arahant Mahinda to King Devanampiyatissa, leading to his conversion and the spread of Buddhism in Sri Lanka. This would have been around 250 BCE.

mn27:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn27:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn27:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo sabbasetena vaḷavābhirathena sāvatthiyā niyyāti divādivassa.
mn27:2.1.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Jānussoṇi drove out from Sāvatthī in the middle of the day in an all-white chariot drawn by mares.
mn27:2.1.comm: A chariot drawn by mares was the preferred vehicle of Jānussoṇi (MN 99:30.1, SN 45.4:1.3), as well as the brahmin student Ambaṭṭha DN 3:1.6.1. Chāndogya Upaniṣad 4.2.1 depicts Jānaśruti’s wealth as including cows, gold, and a chariot drawn by mules.

mn27:2.2.pli: Addasā kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo pilotikaṃ paribbājakaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn27:2.2.eng: He saw the wanderer Pilotika coming off in the distance,
mn27:2.2.comm: Pilotika Vacchāyana is not mentioned elsewhere. His first name means “patch” and may be a reference to his patchwork robe (cp. “Ajita of the hair-blanket”). Vacchāyana is a patronymic, possibly indicating he was of the lineage of Vātsya, a student of Yājñavalkya (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 9.5.1.62, Brahmāṇḍa Purāṇa 2.35.29).

mn27:2.4.pli: “Handa kuto nu bhavaṃ vacchāyano āgacchati divādivassā”ti?
mn27:2.4.eng: “So, worthy Vacchāyana, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”

mn27:2.5.pli: “Ito hi kho ahaṃ, bho, āgacchāmi samaṇassa gotamassa santikā”ti.
mn27:2.5.eng: “Just now, good fellow, I’ve come from the presence of the ascetic Gotama.”

mn27:2.6.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññati bhavaṃ vacchāyano samaṇassa gotamassa paññāveyyattiyaṃ paṇḍito maññe”ti.
mn27:2.6.eng: “What do you think of the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom? Do you think he’s astute?”

mn27:2.7.pli: “Ko cāhaṃ, bho, ko ca samaṇassa gotamassa paññāveyyattiyaṃ jānissāmi.
mn27:2.7.eng: “My good man, who am I to judge the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom?
mn27:2.7.comm: As at MN 99:30.7 and AN 5.194:2.4. The Buddha speaks of his own lucidity of wisdom at MN 12:62.6.

mn27:2.8.pli: Sopi nūnassa tādisova yo samaṇassa gotamassa paññāveyyattiyaṃ jāneyyā”ti.
mn27:2.8.eng: You’d really have to be on the same level to judge his lucidity of wisdom.”

mn27:2.9.pli: “Uḷārāya khalu bhavaṃ vacchāyano samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pasaṃsāya pasaṃsatī”ti.
mn27:2.9.eng: “Mister Vacchāyana praises the ascetic Gotama with high praise indeed.”

mn27:2.10.pli: “Ko cāhaṃ, bho, ko ca samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pasaṃsissāmi,
mn27:2.10.eng: “Who am I to praise the ascetic Gotama?

mn27:2.11.pli: pasatthapasatthova so bhavaṃ gotamo seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti.
mn27:2.11.eng: He is praised by the praised as the first among gods and humans.”

mn27:2.12.pli: “Kaṃ pana bhavaṃ vacchāyano atthavasaṃ sampassamāno samaṇe gotame evaṃ abhippasanno”ti?
mn27:2.12.eng: “But for what reason are you so devoted to the ascetic Gotama?”

mn27:3.1.eng: “Suppose that a skilled bull elephant tracker were to enter a bull elephant wood.
mn27:3.1.comm: The text differentiates “bull elephant” (nāga), “elephant” (hatthi), and “cow elephant” (hatthinī). This is essential to the parable, as the tracker is specifically seeking a bull.

mn27:3.2.pli: So passeyya nāgavane mahantaṃ hatthipadaṃ, dīghato ca āyataṃ, tiriyañca vitthataṃ.
mn27:3.2.eng: There he’d see a large elephant’s footprint, long and broad.

mn27:3.3.eng: He would come to the conclusion,
mn27:3.3.comm: The Pali phrase niṭṭhaṁ gaccheyya is an exact match for the English idiom “come to a conclusion”.

mn27:3.4.eng: ‘This must be a big bull elephant.’

mn27:3.5.pli: Evameva kho ahaṃ, bho, yato addasaṃ samaṇe gotame cattāri padāni athāhaṃ niṭṭhamagamaṃ:
mn27:3.5.eng: In the same way, because I saw four footprints of the ascetic Gotama I came to the conclusion,

mn27:3.6.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn27:3.6.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn27:4.2.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bho, passāmi ekacce khattiyapaṇḍite nipuṇe kataparappavāde vālavedhirūpe, te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni.
mn27:4.2.eng: Firstly, I see some clever aristocrats who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. You’d think they live to demolish convictions with their intellect.

mn27:4.4.pli: ‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo amukaṃ nāma gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā osarissatī’ti.
mn27:4.4.eng: ‘So, gentlemen, that ascetic Gotama will come down to such and such village or town.’

mn27:4.6.pli: ‘imaṃ mayaṃ pañhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchissāma.
mn27:4.6.eng: ‘We’ll approach the ascetic Gotama and ask him this question.

mn27:4.7.pli: Evañce no puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evamassa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāma.
mn27:4.7.eng: If he answers like this, we’ll refute him like that;

mn27:4.8.pli: Evañcepi no puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evampissa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāmā’ti.
mn27:4.8.eng: and if he answers like that, we’ll refute him like this.’

mn27:4.10.pli: ‘samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo amukaṃ nāma gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā osaṭo’ti.

mn27:4.12.pli: Te samaṇo gotamo dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.
mn27:4.12.eng: The ascetic Gotama educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires them with a Dhamma talk.

mn27:4.13.pli: Te samaṇena gotamena dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā na ceva samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pañhaṃ pucchanti, kutossa vādaṃ āropessanti?
mn27:4.13.eng: They don’t even get around to asking their question to the ascetic Gotama, so how could they refute his answer?

mn27:4.15.pli: Yadāhaṃ, bho, samaṇe gotame imaṃ paṭhamaṃ padaṃ addasaṃ athāhaṃ niṭṭhamagamaṃ:
mn27:4.15.eng: When I saw this first footprint of the ascetic Gotama, I came to the conclusion,

mn27:4.16.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn27:4.16.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn27:5.1.pli: Puna caparāhaṃ, bho, passāmi idhekacce brāhmaṇapaṇḍite …pe…
mn27:5.1.eng: Furthermore, I see some clever brahmins …

mn27:7.1.pli: samaṇapaṇḍite nipuṇe kataparappavāde vālavedhirūpe te bhindantā maññe caranti paññāgatena diṭṭhigatāni.
mn27:7.1.eng: Furthermore, I see some clever ascetics who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. …

mn27:7.3.pli: ‘samaṇo khalu bho gotamo amukaṃ nāma gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā osarissatī’ti.

mn27:7.4.pli: Te pañhaṃ abhisaṅkharonti ‘imaṃ mayaṃ pañhaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pucchissāma.

mn27:7.5.pli: Evañce no puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evamassa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāma.

mn27:7.6.pli: Evañcepi no puṭṭho evaṃ byākarissati, evampissa mayaṃ vādaṃ āropessāmā’ti.

mn27:7.7.pli: Te suṇanti ‘samaṇo khalu bho gotamo amukaṃ nāma gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā osaṭo’ti.

mn27:7.9.pli: Te samaṇo gotamo dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti.

mn27:7.10.pli: Te samaṇena gotamena dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā na ceva samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pañhaṃ pucchanti, kutossa vādaṃ āropessanti?
mn27:7.10.eng: They don’t even get around to asking their question to the ascetic Gotama, so how could they refute his answer?

mn27:7.11.pli: Aññadatthu samaṇaṃyeva gotamaṃ okāsaṃ yācanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.
mn27:7.11.eng: Invariably, they ask the ascetic Gotama for the chance to go forth.

mn27:7.12.eng: And he gives them the going-forth.

mn27:7.13.pli: Te tattha pabbajitā samānā vūpakaṭṭhā appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharantā nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
mn27:7.13.eng: Soon after going forth, living withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, they realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. They live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn27:7.15.pli: ‘manaṃ vata, bho, anassāma, manaṃ vata, bho, panassāma;
mn27:7.15.eng: ‘We were almost lost! We almost perished!

mn27:7.16.pli: mayañhi pubbe assamaṇāva samānā samaṇamhāti paṭijānimha, abrāhmaṇāva samānā brāhmaṇamhāti paṭijānimha, anarahantova samānā arahantamhāti paṭijānimha.
mn27:7.16.eng: For we used to claim that we were ascetics, brahmins, and perfected ones, but we were none of these things.

mn27:7.17.pli: Idāni khomha samaṇā, idāni khomha brāhmaṇā, idāni khomha arahanto’ti.
mn27:7.17.eng: But now we really are ascetics, brahmins, and perfected ones!’

mn27:7.18.pli: Yadāhaṃ, bho, samaṇe gotame imaṃ catutthaṃ padaṃ addasaṃ athāhaṃ niṭṭhamagamaṃ:
mn27:7.18.eng: When I saw this fourth footprint of the ascetic Gotama, I came to the conclusion,

mn27:7.19.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn27:7.19.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn27:7.20.pli: Yato kho ahaṃ, bho, samaṇe gotame imāni cattāri padāni addasaṃ athāhaṃ niṭṭhamagamaṃ:
mn27:7.20.eng: It’s because I saw these four footprints of the ascetic Gotama that I came to the conclusion,

mn27:7.21.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’”ti.
mn27:7.21.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’”

mn27:8.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo sabbasetā vaḷavābhirathā orohitvā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
mn27:8.1.eng: When he had spoken, Jānussoṇi got down from his chariot, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:

mn27:8.2.eng: “Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

mn27:8.3.eng: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

mn27:8.4.eng: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

mn27:8.5.pli: Appeva nāma mayampi kadāci karahaci tena bhotā gotamena saddhiṃ samāgaccheyyāma, appeva nāma siyā kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti.
mn27:8.5.eng: Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet the worthy Gotama, and we can have a discussion.”

mn27:9.1.pli: Atha kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn27:9.1.eng: Then the brahmin Jānussoṇi went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

mn27:9.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn27:9.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,

mn27:9.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo yāvatako ahosi pilotikena paribbājakena saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato ārocesi.
mn27:9.3.eng: and informed the Buddha of all he had discussed with the wanderer Pilotika.

mn27:9.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā jāṇussoṇiṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
mn27:9.4.eng: When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,

mn27:9.5.pli: “na kho, brāhmaṇa, ettāvatā hatthipadopamo vitthārena paripūro hoti.
mn27:9.5.eng: “Brahmin, the simile of the elephant’s footprint is not yet completed in detail.

mn27:9.6.pli: Api ca, brāhmaṇa, yathā hatthipadopamo vitthārena paripūro hoti
mn27:9.6.eng: As to how it is completed in detail,

mn27:9.7.pli: taṃ suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn27:9.7.eng: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn27:9.8.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavato paccassosi.

mn27:10.1.eng: “Suppose a bull elephant tracker were to enter a bull elephant wood.

mn27:10.2.pli: So passeyya nāgavane mahantaṃ hatthipadaṃ, dīghato ca āyataṃ, tiriyañca vitthataṃ.
mn27:10.2.eng: There they’d see a large elephant’s footprint, long and broad.

mn27:10.3.pli: Yo hoti kusalo nāgavaniko neva tāva niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:
mn27:10.3.eng: A skilled bull elephant tracker does not yet come to the conclusion,

mn27:10.4.eng: ‘This must be a big bull elephant.’

mn27:10.6.pli: Santi hi, brāhmaṇa, nāgavane vāmanikā nāma hatthiniyo mahāpadā, tāsaṃ petaṃ padaṃ assāti.
mn27:10.6.eng: Because in an elephant wood there are dwarf cow elephants with big footprints, and this footprint might be one of theirs.
mn27:10.6.comm: This passage names three kinds of cow elephants unknown elsewhere. From the context they must be of ascending height. The first is the “dwarf” (vāmanikā).

mn27:10.8.pli: Tamanugacchanto passati nāgavane mahantaṃ hatthipadaṃ, dīghato ca āyataṃ, tiriyañca vitthataṃ, uccā ca nisevitaṃ.
mn27:10.8.eng: They keep following the track until they see a big footprint, long and broad, and traces high up.

mn27:10.9.pli: Yo hoti kusalo nāgavaniko neva tāva niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:
mn27:10.9.eng: A skilled bull elephant tracker does not yet come to the conclusion,

mn27:10.10.eng: ‘This must be a big bull elephant.’

mn27:10.12.pli: Santi hi, brāhmaṇa, nāgavane uccā kāḷārikā nāma hatthiniyo mahāpadā, tāsaṃ petaṃ padaṃ assāti.
mn27:10.12.eng: Because in an elephant wood there are tall lofty cow elephants with big footprints, and this footprint might be one of theirs.
mn27:10.12.comm: Kāḷārikā is related to Sanskrit karāla, which may mean “lofty” or “with gaping teeth”. The commentary applies the latter meaning, but surely the former fits the context.

mn27:10.14.pli: Tamanugacchanto passati nāgavane mahantaṃ hatthipadaṃ, dīghato ca āyataṃ, tiriyañca vitthataṃ, uccā ca nisevitaṃ, uccā ca dantehi ārañjitāni.
mn27:10.14.eng: They keep following the track until they see a big footprint, long and broad, and traces and tusk-marks high up.

mn27:10.15.pli: Yo hoti kusalo nāgavaniko neva tāva niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:
mn27:10.15.eng: A skilled bull elephant tracker does not yet come to the conclusion,

mn27:10.16.eng: ‘This must be a big bull elephant.’

mn27:10.18.pli: Santi hi, brāhmaṇa, nāgavane uccā kaṇerukā nāma hatthiniyo mahāpadā, tāsaṃ petaṃ padaṃ assāti.
mn27:10.18.eng: Because in an elephant wood there are tall matriarch cow elephants with big footprints, and this footprint might be one of theirs.
mn27:10.18.comm: One of the many Indic names for elephants, especially cows, is kareṇu (Pali kaṇeru by metathesis), which, being from the root kara (“doer” = “hand”), has the same meaning as the more common hatthi, namely “handy”. I think the kaṇerukā is the “leader of the cows”, i.e. the matriarch.

mn27:10.20.pli: Tamanugacchanto passati nāgavane mahantaṃ hatthipadaṃ, dīghato ca āyataṃ, tiriyañca vitthataṃ, uccā ca nisevitaṃ, uccā ca dantehi ārañjitāni, uccā ca sākhābhaṅgaṃ.
mn27:10.20.eng: They keep following the track until they see a big footprint, long and broad, and traces, tusk-marks, and broken branches high up.

mn27:10.21.pli: Tañca nāgaṃ passati rukkhamūlagataṃ vā abbhokāsagataṃ vā gacchantaṃ vā tiṭṭhantaṃ vā nisinnaṃ vā nipannaṃ vā.
mn27:10.21.eng: And they see that bull elephant walking, standing, sitting, or lying down at the root of a tree or in the open.

mn27:10.22.eng: Then they’d come to the conclusion,

mn27:11.1.pli: Evameva kho, brāhmaṇa, idha tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā.
mn27:11.1.eng: In the same way, brahmin, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
mn27:11.1.comm: This is the start of the teaching on the Gradual Training, encompassing ethics (sīla), meditation (samādhi), and wisdom (paññā).

mn27:11.2.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
mn27:11.2.eng: He realizes with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

mn27:11.3.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ; kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
mn27:11.3.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely complete and pure.

mn27:12.1.pli: Taṃ dhammaṃ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṃ vā kule paccājāto.
mn27:12.1.eng: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.

mn27:12.2.pli: So taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhati.
mn27:12.2.eng: They gain faith in the Realized One,

mn27:12.3.pli: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:

mn27:12.4.eng: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.

mn27:12.5.pli: Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
mn27:12.5.eng: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

mn27:12.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
mn27:12.6.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn27:12.7.pli: So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
mn27:12.7.eng: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn27:13.1.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṃ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
mn27:13.1.eng: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
mn27:13.1.comm: The first and most important precept. It is not just the negative injunction to avoid killing, but also the positive injunction to have compassion for all creatures. If a monastic murders a human being they are immediately and permanently expelled.

mn27:13.2.pli: Adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī. Athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
mn27:13.2.eng: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
mn27:13.2.comm: To steal anything of substantial value is an expulsion offence.

mn27:13.3.pli: Abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
mn27:13.3.eng: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
mn27:13.3.comm: “Chastity” is brahmacariya, literally “divine conduct”. Here it is used in the narrow sense of refraining from sex, but more commonly it has a broader sense of “spiritual life”. Buddhist monastics are forbidden from any form of sexual activity. To engage in penetrative intercourse is an expulsion offence.

mn27:13.4.pli: Musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassa.
mn27:13.4.eng: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
mn27:13.4.comm: This is the first of the four kinds of right speech. Just as the precept of not killing implies the positive injunction to live with compassion, the precepts on speech enjoin a positive and constructive use of speech. If a monastic falsely claims states of enlightenment or deep meditation they are expelled.

mn27:13.5.pli: Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā amūsaṃ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
mn27:13.5.eng: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
mn27:13.5.comm: “Harmony” (or “unanimity”, samagga) does not excuse untrue, bigoted, or otherwise harmful speech. True harmony is only achieved in the presence of the Dhamma.

mn27:13.6.pli: Pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti. Yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
mn27:13.6.eng: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable, and agreeable to the people.

mn27:13.7.pli: Samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ.
mn27:13.7.eng: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
mn27:13.7.comm: Attha is a polyvalent term, here taking the senses “meaningful” and “beneficial”. Elsewhere it means “goal”, “need”, “purpose”, “lawsuit”, or “ending”, and the senses are not always easy to untangle.

mn27:13.8.eng: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
mn27:13.8.comm: Buddhists generally do not regard plants as sentient, but value them as part of the ecosystem that supports all life.

mn27:13.9.eng: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and at the wrong time.
mn27:13.9.comm: From MN 66:6.4 and MN 70:4.8 we can see that “at night” means after dark, while “at the wrong time” means in the afternoon. More explicitly, these are the “wrong time at night” and the “wrong time in the day”, in which case they are both the “wrong time”.

mn27:13.10.eng: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music.
mn27:13.10.comm: Such sensual entertainments distract and excite the mind. This and the next three precepts encourage peace of mind for meditation.

mn27:13.11.eng: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
mn27:13.11.comm: This was ignored by the Buddha’s cousin, Nanda (SN 21.8:1.2).

mn27:13.12.eng: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.

mn27:13.13.eng: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
mn27:13.13.comm: Literally “gold and silver” (jātarūparajata), but rajata is explained in Bu NP 18:2.8 as currency of any kind.

mn27:13.14.comm: Mendicants receive only the day’s meal and do not store or cook food.

mn27:13.17.comm: According to ancient Indian law (Arthaśāstra 3.13), a person in a time of trouble may bind themselves in service for a fee. Such bondservants were protected against cruelty, sexual abuse, and unfair work. After earning back the fee of their indenture they were freed, retaining their original inheritance and status.

mn27:13.18.comm: These are animals raised for food.

mn27:13.21.comm: Land for a monastery may be accepted by the Saṅgha as a community, but not by individual mendicants.

mn27:13.22.eng: They refrain from running errands and messages;
mn27:13.22.comm: These items are discussed in detail below. | Acting as a go-between for lay business was tempting due to the mendicants’ wandering lifestyle. However, it exposes them to risk if the message is not delivered or if it is bad news.

mn27:13.23.comm: For example, trading in monastery property.

mn27:13.26.eng: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

mn27:14.1.pli: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
mn27:14.1.eng: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
mn27:14.1.comm: A Buddhist monk has three robes: a lower robe (sabong or sarong), an upper robe, and an outer cloak. | Here begins the series of practices that build on moral fundamentals to lay the groundwork for meditation. The sequence of contentment, mindfulness, and sense restraint sometimes varies (eg. DN 2:64.1).

mn27:14.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti sapattabhārova ḍeti;
mn27:14.2.eng: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.

mn27:14.3.pli: evameva bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
mn27:14.3.eng: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

mn27:14.4.pli: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ anavajjasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
mn27:14.4.eng: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
mn27:14.4.comm: As at DN 2:63.4. This phrase perhaps belongs before contentment.

mn27:15.1.pli: So cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
mn27:15.1.eng: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

mn27:15.2.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
mn27:15.2.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
mn27:15.2.comm: It is not that one cannot see things, but that, mindful of its effect, one avoids unnecessary stimulation. | “Covetousness and bitterness” (abhijjhā domanassā) are the strong forms of desire and aversion caused by lack of restraint.

mn27:15.3.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

mn27:15.4.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

mn27:15.5.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

mn27:15.6.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

mn27:15.7.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
mn27:15.7.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

mn27:15.8.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
mn27:15.8.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

mn27:15.9.pli: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṃ abyāsekasukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeti.
mn27:15.9.eng: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
mn27:15.9.comm: As at DN 2:64.10, their happiness deepens, as they see that not only their actions but also their mind is becoming free of anything unwholesome.

mn27:16.1.pli: So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
mn27:16.1.eng: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
mn27:16.1.comm: Situational awareness is a psychological term popularized in the 1990s. It has to do with the perception of environmental phenomena and the comprehension of their meaning, which is very close to the sense of the Pali term sampajañña. | These acts describe the daily life of a mendicant: going into the village for alms, at which time there are many distracting sights. Then they return, eat their meal, and spend their day in meditation.

mn27:17.1.pli: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṃvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato
mn27:17.1.eng: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,

mn27:17.2.pli: vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ.
mn27:17.2.eng: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
mn27:17.2.comm: The Jain Ācārāṅgasūtra 1.8.2 notes many places used by Mahāvīra for meditation, including a charnel ground, an empty hut, and the root of a tree.

mn27:18.1.pli: So pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā, ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
mn27:18.1.eng: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
mn27:18.1.comm: For parimukha (“in their presence”) we find pratimukha in Sanskrit, which can mean “presence” or the reflection of the face. Late canonical Pali explains parimukha as “the tip of the nose or the reflection of the face (mukhanimitta)”. Parimukha in Sanskrit is rare, but it appears in Pāṇini 4.4.29, which the commentary illustrates with the example of a servant “in the presence” of their master (cp. SN 47.8). So it seems the sense is “before the face” or more generally “in the presence”. | To “establish mindfulness” (satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā) is literally to “do satipaṭṭhāna”.

mn27:18.2.pli: So abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn27:18.2.eng: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
mn27:18.2.comm: Covetousness (abhijjha) has been curbed by sense restraint, and now is fully abandoned.

mn27:18.3.pli: Byāpādapadosaṃ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī byāpādapadosā cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn27:18.3.eng: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
mn27:18.3.comm: Likewise ill will (byāpādapadosa), which was called domanassa in the formula for sense restraint.

mn27:18.4.pli: Thinamiddhaṃ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn27:18.4.eng: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
mn27:18.4.comm: “Mindfulness and situational awareness” has a prominent role in abandoning dullness.

mn27:18.5.pli: Uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahāya anuddhato viharati, ajjhattaṃ vūpasantacitto uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn27:18.5.eng: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
mn27:18.5.comm: Restlessness hankers for the future and is countered by contentment. Remorse digs up the past and is countered by ethical purity.

mn27:18.6.pli: Vicikicchaṃ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṃ parisodheti.
mn27:18.6.eng: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
mn27:18.6.comm: The meditator set out on their path after gaining faith in the Buddha.

mn27:19.1.pli: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe,
mn27:19.1.eng: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
mn27:19.1.comm: The five hindrances remain a pillar of meditation teaching. The root sense means to “obstruct” but also to “obscure, darken, veil”.

mn27:19.2.pli: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn27:19.2.eng: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn27:19.3.pli: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṃ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṃ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṃ itipi.
mn27:19.3.eng: This, brahmin, is that which is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ and also ‘a trace of the Realized One’ and also ‘a mark of the Realized One’.
mn27:19.3.comm: The first true footprint of the Buddha is jhāna, not skill in debate or conversion, nor even ethical conduct. Compare DN 2:76.3, where jhāna was the first superior fruit of the spiritual life.

mn27:19.4.pli: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:
mn27:19.4.eng: But a noble disciple does not yet come to the conclusion,
mn27:19.4.comm: Just as the bull elephant tracker does not come to a conclusion until they have found a bull elephant, here the meditator has not confirmed that the Buddha’s teaching leads to the goal that was promised.

mn27:19.5.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn27:19.5.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn27:20.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn27:20.1.eng: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn27:20.2.eng: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …

mn27:21.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn27:21.1.eng: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

mn27:21.2.eng: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …

mn27:22.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
mn27:22.1.eng: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn27:22.2.pli: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṃ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṃ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṃ itipi.
mn27:22.2.eng: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …

mn27:22.3.pli: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:

mn27:22.4.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.

mn27:23.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn27:23.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.

mn27:23.2.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ, dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati.
mn27:23.2.eng: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

mn27:23.3.pli: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṃ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṃ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṃ itipi.
mn27:23.3.eng: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …

mn27:23.4.pli: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:

mn27:23.5.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.

mn27:24.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn27:24.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.

mn27:24.2.pli: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
mn27:24.2.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human, they understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

mn27:24.3.pli: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṃ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṃ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṃ itipi.
mn27:24.3.eng: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …

mn27:24.4.pli: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:

mn27:24.5.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.

mn27:25.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmeti.
mn27:25.1.eng: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

mn27:25.2.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn27:25.2.eng: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

mn27:25.3.pli: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
mn27:25.3.eng: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’

mn27:25.4.pli: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṃ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṃ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṃ itipi.
mn27:25.4.eng: This, brahmin, is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ and also ‘a trace of the Realized One’ and also ‘a mark of the Realized One’.

mn27:25.5.pli: Na tveva tāva ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṃ gato hoti, api ca kho niṭṭhaṃ gacchati:
mn27:25.5.eng: At this point a noble disciple has not yet come to a conclusion, but they are coming to the conclusion,
mn27:25.5.comm: They are in the culminating stages of the path.

mn27:25.6.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn27:25.6.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn27:26.1.pli: Tassa evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccati.
mn27:26.1.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

mn27:26.2.eng: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn27:26.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
mn27:26.3.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

mn27:26.4.pli: Idampi vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tathāgatapadaṃ itipi, tathāgatanisevitaṃ itipi, tathāgatārañjitaṃ itipi.
mn27:26.4.eng: This, brahmin, is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ and also ‘a trace of the Realized One’ and also ‘a mark of the Realized One’.

mn27:26.5.pli: Ettāvatā kho, brāhmaṇa, ariyasāvako niṭṭhaṃ gato hoti:
mn27:26.5.eng: At this point a noble disciple has come to the conclusion,
mn27:26.5.comm: Faith, reason, evidence, and experience have all played a role in the discovery of truth. But there can be no certainty until the truth has accomplished its ultimate function, freedom from suffering.

mn27:26.6.pli: ‘sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo, suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho’ti.
mn27:26.6.eng: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’

mn27:26.7.pli: Ettāvatā kho, brāhmaṇa, hatthipadopamo vitthārena paripūro hotī”ti.
mn27:26.7.eng: And it is at this point that the simile of the elephant’s footprint has been completed in detail.”

mn27:27.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn27:27.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Jānussoṇi said to the Buddha,

mn27:27.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
mn27:27.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

mn27:27.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
mn27:27.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

mn27:27.5.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
mn27:27.5.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
